direction.question: A DFA can proccess inputs from left to right OR right to left.
correctFeedback: A DFA can only start at the left (the first letter of the input string) and move to the right (the last letter of the input string).

readonly.question: DFAs can be used to add more letters to the given input.
correctFeedback: A DFA can not modfiy the tape. It can only look at it or 'read' it.

whichstate.description: Look at the DFA schematic diagram above.
whichstate.question: What state is the control unit in?

whatdefinition.description:
We are going to talk about many DFAs. And you will build some yourself. So we need a precise definition for a DFA actually is. Think about this a moment: What do we need to completely specify a DFA and its behavior? We want to define the DFA with the parts that are needed, and nothing more.

One more thing that you need to know: Some states in the machine are labeled as 'final' states. If at the end of processing the string the machine is in a 'final state, then the machine outputs 'yes', otherwise it outputs 'no'.
whatdefinition.question: Which of the following need to be in the definition of a DFA?
answer: a set of transitions that define, given a state and a current symbol, what state to go to
choices: a set of transitions that define, given a state and a current symbol, what state to go to
a set of transitions that define, given a state and a current symbol, what state to go to, and where to move the tape head
incorrectFeedback: Hint: You will need exactly 5 of these things.

determine.description: We interpret the DFA as outputting a value of 'yes' or 'accept' on a given input string if the DFA ends processing of that string in a final state, and we say that the DFA outputs 'no' or 'reject' if it is not in a final state at the end of processing that string.
determine.question: A DFA can end in different states on different runs when given the same string as the input.

states.description: $Q$ is a set of all the states in the DFA. In our graph representation, this is the set of nodes for the graph.
states.question: Which of the following represents $Q$?

alphabet.description: $\Sigma$ is the input alphabet, the set of symbols that can appear in the input for the DFA. In the graph, these can appear as labels on the edges.
alphabet.question: Which of the following is $\Sigma$ for this DFA??

transitions.description: $\delta$ is the set of transtions between the states in the form $(q_i, a) \rightarrow q_j$. In other words, a transition is defined by a state and an input symbol, and it tells what to do in that case (which is to be in some state after consuming the symbol). Transitions are represented by edges in the graph, and the labels tell what symbol(s) can be processed by that transition.
transitions.question: What is $\delta$(q0, 0)?

delta.description: $\delta$ is the set of transtions between the states in the form $(q_i, a) \rightarrow q_j$. In other words, a transition is defined by a state and an input symbol, and it tells what to do in that case (which is to be in some state after consuming the symbol). Transitions are represented by edges in the graph, and the labels tell what symbol(s) can be processed by that transition.
delta.question: What is  $\delta$(q1, 1)?

deltatable.description:
$\delta$ is sometimes expressed in tabular format to show all possible transitions. $\begin{array}{r|cc}
      & 0  & 1 \\
      \hline
      q0 &  &  \\
      q1 &  &  \\
      \end{array}$
deltatable.question: Which of these is the $\delta$ for this example?
answer:
\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1
 \\ \hline q0 & q1 & q0 \\ q1 & q1 & q0 \\ \end{array}
choices:
\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1 \\ \hline q0 & q0 & q0 \\ 
q1 & q1 & q1 \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1
 \\ \hline q0 & q1 & q0 \\ q1 & q1 & q0 \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{r|cc} & 0 & 1 \\ \hline q0 & q0 & q1 \\ q1
 & q0 & q1 \\ \end{array}

start.description: $Q_0$ is the start state of the DFA. Every DFA has to define which state to start in, so there is only one start state. We show the start state by putting a triangle next to it.
start.question: Which of the following is the start state for this DFA?

final.description: $F$ is a set of all the final states. We show these states in the graph with double circles for those nodes.
final.question: Which of the following represents $F$ for this DFA?
final.correctFeedback: $F$ is a set. It so happens that this DFA has only one final state (so its a set of one state). Other machines might have multiple final states.

whygraph.description: The DFA shown as a graph below can be expressed in text as: $M = (Q,\Sigma,\delta,Q_0,F) = (\{q0,q1\},\{0,1\},\delta,q_0,\{q1\})$. We would also need to add a description for the $\delta$ transitions.
whygraph.question: Which representation makes it easier to grasp the behavior the machine? The text or the graph?

semantics.description: A way to make it even easier to understand the behavior of a DFA is to assign semantic meaning to the states. In this example, the machine is in state $q_0$ when the digits proccessed so far make the input an odd number (the last symbol seen is '1'), and the machine is in state $q_1$ when the digits processed so far make the input an even number (the last symbol seen is '0').
semantics.question: Which of the following strings will be accepted?
